description: Dive into "Whispers of Love in Sendai" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Whispers of Love in Sendai

places.generalDescription: When visiting Sendai, Japan, be sure to try the local specialty known as Gyutan. This dish features beef tongue that is sliced and lightly grilled, offering a unique and delicious dining experience. One popular spot to enjoy Gyutan is at Gyutan Kaku - Vlandome, a well-designed restaurant known for perfectly cooked dishes. While the staff may not speak fluent English, they are attentive and helpful in guiding diners through the menu.

sources.snippet: Sendai's most famous cuisine is gyutan, grilled beef tongue. With over 100 restaurants selling this juicy delicacy, it is probably more famous than even Date Masamune!. If you are not a meat fan, Sendai is also famous for its cold chinese noodles, miso, sake, traditional sweets, oysters and sushi from nearby towns, zunda mochi (crushed soy bean rice cakes) and more.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Things To Do in Sendai - Sendai, Miyagi

sources.snippet: When it comes to Sendai’s signature cuisine, gyutan (grilled beef tongue) is a must-try. Thickly sliced and expertly seasoned, the meat is aged for maximum flavor before being grilled over charcoal, creating a juicy yet tender bite with a signature smoky aroma.
sources.shortName: 38 Best Things to Do in Sendai & Miyagi: Sightseeing, Food, Shopping & Souvenirs

places.name: Kaku

reviews.text: Very popular place for gyutan and for good reason! We came for lunch 3 minutes before they opened and just made it in for the first seating. The tomatoes were delicious and the beef tongue was seasoned perfectly, thick and chewy. The barley rice was also excellent. Definitely the best place to get gyutan and worth the money & wait in my opinion!

We arrived 20 minutes before dinner service and were lucky to be among the first to get a table. The atmosphere is warm and inviting, making it a perfect place to enjoy a meal.

The gyutan was incredible-perfectly grilled, tender, and full of rich flavor. Easily the best I've ever had! The tataki was also outstanding, with a delicate texture and deep umami taste. To complete the meal, we added tororo to the rice, which made everything even more satisfying.

If you love gyutan, this is a must-visit spot. Highly recommended!

Fresh and great beef tongue, perfectly grilled, tasty, bouncy texture. You will love here if you are a fan of beef tongue. The included soup is soso. The appetizer, beer is good. The price is high, could find more satisfaction with this cost.

places.address: Japan, 〒980-0811 Miyagi, Sendai, Aoba Ward, Ichibancho, 3 Chome−8−14 鈴喜陶器店, 地下1階

places.generalDescription: Zuihōden, the final resting place of Date Masamune, stands as a testament to the rich history of Sendai and its most influential feudal lord. Constructed in 1637 by his successor, Lord Tadamune, this mausoleum showcases stunning Momoyama architectural style with vibrant carvings that capture the essence of the Edo Period.

sources.snippet: Its brilliant, multicolored decorations have conserved the characteristics of the culture during that period. The road to the mausoleum is surrounded by trees, creating a very spiritual, nature-filled ambiance. There are beautiful hydrangeas during the rainy season, red and yellow leaves during the fall, and a snowy landscape in the winter, making this a spot where you can enjoy views of each season.
sources.shortName: Top 20 Things to Do in Sendai: Travel Guide 2024

sources.snippet: Explore landmarks like Sendai Castle and Zuihoden, marvel at Matsushima’s coastal beauty, or visit the volcanic Okama Crater. Savor fresh local cuisine and experience seasonal events like the Sendai Tanabata Festival and the Sendai Pageant of Starlight. This guide covers must-see spots, food, and nearby attractions.
sources.shortName: 38 Best Things to Do in Sendai & Miyagi: Sightseeing, Food, Shopping & Souvenirs

sources.snippet: Zuihoden is the mausoleum of Date Masamune built after his death in 1636. Zuihoden was completed in 1637, four years after the death of Date Masamune. The design of the Zuihoden is in the ornate style of the Azuchi-Momoyama Period (1573-1603).
sources.shortName: 6 Best Things to Do in Sendai

sources.snippet: This mausoleum was built in accordance with the last command of Date Masamune, the founder of the Sendai domain, who passed away at the age of 70. Address: 23-2 Reiyashita, Aoba Ward, Sendai City
sources.siteName: ホテルグランバッハ - Hotel GrandBach
sources.shortName: Sendai: Local sightseeing | Hotel GrandBach
35 things to do in Sendai: Festivals, nature, and attractions
Romantic Tour In Sendai – Opatrip

places.name: Zuihōden (Grave of Date Masamune)

reviews.text: June 24, 2025 Rain this morning but bus ride from Sendai Station no problem. Short walk up hill to Zuihoden. It was like going back in time

A very peaceful site with a trail that walks you around the forest. There are various tombs and also a cemetery dedicated to children which is located in a beautiful scenic open area of the woods.

Overall I would say it was nice but I would consider it a little pricey considering the size of the site. We paid 500 yen per person.

The good thing is that there are free parking spots very close to the entrance and it is enough to show them the tickets you bought when coming back.

I would say that if you have an hour to space in Sentai this one might be a good alternative to consider.

Zuihoden was originally built in 1637 but due to war and other reasons, the current worship and memorial shrine was rebuilt in 1979 and repaired in 2001. It is the building complex of the burial chamber of Date Masamune, feudal lord and founder of modern Sendai city, and his heirs.

The building complex is rich colorful splendid in design and elegantly painted, while outside roads to the Zuihoden are surrounded by tall trees and quasi forest.

It seems that Zuihoden is more attractive, especially for foreign visitors, for area outside the worship hall, such as forest-style roads which have stylish beauty.  On the contrary, the worship hall and grave inside is rather contemporary rebuilt with historical importance and meaning perhaps for local residents, but it may be a stranger historical anecdote which is less attractive for foreign visitors or even out-of-town Japanese visitors for remote association of the local lord. This reflection and comment are based on observation that fewer visitors took photos in front of Zuihoden worship hall and nearby building, while most visitors did have photo taking at forest-style roads.

Compared to other tour attractions in Sendai, Zuihoden probably has the best bilingual explanation postings at its site, and it does help foreign visitors for viewing.

The entrance ticket for Zuihoden is $570 Yen, although it can be reduced to $460 Yen for Sendai Loople ticket holder.

places.address: 23-2 Otamayashita, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0814, Japan

places.generalDescription: Sendai Station serves as a fantastic starting point for exploring the rich cultural and natural wonders of Miyagi Prefecture. Just a short 30-minute drive west leads you to Akiu Onsen, one of Tohoku's renowned hot springs with a history dating back around 1,500 years. Legend has it that Emperor Kinmei found relief from his skin ailment after bathing in its healing waters, while the famous warrior Date Masamune frequented this serene spot.

sources.snippet: You can fly from Narita to the Sendai Airport or you can experience the bullet train (Shinkansen) that will take you to Sendai station in 1 hour and 30 minutes!. We recommend trying the Shinkansen not just for the amazing experience of travelling on one of the fastest trains in the world, but also for the convenience of getting from the heart of Tokyo (Tokyo station) to the heart of Miyagi (Sendai station) without having to check in at the airport. This will save you a lot of time to dedicate the thousands of activities you can enjoy in Miyagi Prefecture!
sources.shortName: MIYAGI | TOHOKU x TOKYO (JAPAN)

sources.snippet: Experience the mystical night ambiance of Zuihouden and Sendai Castle during the captivating events of the “Sendai Tanabata Festival” from the 6th to the 8th of August. Zuihouden, the mausoleum of Lord Date Masamune, is adorned with traditional bamboo Tanabata decorations, creating a stunning visual display. The stone steps along the approach to Zuihouden are illuminated by elegant bamboo lanterns, serving as a gateway to a magical world.
sources.shortName: Wonderful Journey to Enjoy Romantic Summer Nights at “Sendai Tanabata Festival”

places.name: Sendai Station

reviews.text: A major train hub that connects Sendai to other Japanese cities. The station itself is massive and contains a lot of stores and shops. Facilities are complete and clean. Many unique stores that sells unique merchandise and local treats. Easily accessible using public transport. West exit is where most of the major Sendai's attractions are. East exit also has a lot of great restaurants and eateries, also a large Daiso and Yodobashi electronics store.

Sendai Station has very clear direction for mapping, including exit numbers and their mapping directions. It links Sendai City Center to Sendai Airport and other major tour attractions, such as Matsushima Island, and other cities with bullet trains.

There is a tourist information office, located inside with JR ticketing customer office.

While Sendai Station is very clean and well maintenance, it is very crowded at space near certain specific exits, probably because locals, friends, etc., like to use Sendai Station as gathering points for parties, dinner, shopping and other activities. Thus, when Sendai has hotter weather, Sendai Station can be even more crowded with young people waiting at near Exits.

For people who stop over Sendai Station in early August, they may get the chance to enjoy the view of Sendai Tanabata [Starlight] Festival, with Tanabata Decoration [Streamer] displays. Compared to more colorful and more exaggerated styles of Tanabata decorations at other sites, such as Chuo-dori and Ichibancho-dori in the Sendai city center, Tanabata decorations at Sendai Station are relatively compact, shorter and thinner, less exaggerated.  But they probably serve as the first shock of experiencing Tanabata decorations for the tourists who stop over Sendai, either they visit Sendai by JR bullet trains or by airplanes and transfer to Sendai by train again.

There are gift shops, restaurants, bakeries, etc. at the 1st and 2nd floors of the Sendai Station, and almost every exit will lead visitors to different dining quarter or shopping mall's food courts.

Sendai Station is a hot spot for tourists and locals alike, with a variety of shops and restaurants to suit your taste and budget. You can find everything from souvenirs and department stores to local delicacies and international cuisines.

One of the highlights of Sendai Station is the the row of restaurants that serve Sendai's famous grilled beef tongue. This is a specialty dish that is tender, juicy and flavorful. However, be prepared to wait in line, as these restaurants are very popular and often have long queues.

To conclude, like other Japanese major train stations, Sendai Station is more than just a transportation hub. It is a destination in itself, where you can experience the culture and cuisine of Sendai.

places.address: 1 Chome-1-1 Central, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0021, Japan

places.generalDescription: Sendai Castle Honmaru Ruins, also known as Aoba Castle, was built in 1602 after Tokugawa Ieyasu's victory at the Battle of Sekigahara. Although it never had a main keep, it featured an impressive honmaru and multi-storied yagura. The castle town was divided into merchant and residential areas to the east and the castle to the west.

sources.snippet: Experience the mystical night ambiance of Zuihouden and Sendai Castle during the captivating events of the “Sendai Tanabata Festival” from the 6th to the 8th of August. Zuihouden, the mausoleum of Lord Date Masamune, is adorned with traditional bamboo Tanabata decorations, creating a stunning visual display. The stone steps along the approach to Zuihouden are illuminated by elegant bamboo lanterns, serving as a gateway to a magical world.
sources.shortName: Wonderful Journey to Enjoy Romantic Summer Nights at “Sendai Tanabata Festival”

sources.snippet: Sendai Castle, which is also known as Aoba Castle, is the ruins of the former castle, occupying a prominent location on top of a hill in the western part of the city. The castle was built and founded by the famous feudal lord Date Masamune in 1610. A statue of Masamune riding a horse looking down to the city can be found at the entrance to the castle grounds, offering visitors nice views of the city.
sources.shortName: Sendai Travel Guide - 9 Best things to do in Sendai

places.name: Sendai Castle Honmaru Ruins

reviews.text: A great place to come visit and explore the beauty of Japanese culture. There are shops selling souvenirs, food, and good luck charms.

Great view of the city of Sendai from up at the hill where the castle once stood. The only thing up here is the statue, shrine, and gift shops. The castle is no longer here, so I don't think tourists will miss much if they don't come here. Plus the trek up the hill can be tiring, unless you pay for the loople bus but it can be crowded and takes a long time to come.

Overpriced. Parking was expensive and the museum was really expensive for what is just a single room of exhibits and a video. The video was cute, and I liked the talking edamame, but not worth the price of admission. The gift shop is decent. The best part is the small recreated display room across from the statue of the horse. We almost missed it because it just looks like a bathroom. Don't make that mistake!

places.address: Kawauchi, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0862, Japan

places.generalDescription: The Sendai Tanabata Festival, also known as the Star Festival, is an annual event held in Sendai, Japan between August 6th and 8th. It is one of the largest and most famous Tanabata festivals in the country. The festival celebrates the once-annual meeting of the lovers Orihime and Hikiboshi, represented by the stars Altair and Vega according to Chinese legend.

sources.snippet: Tanabata festivals which are also known as ‘star festivals’ is an annual festival held all over Japan on the 7th day of the 7th month of the year, when according to Chinese legend, the two stars Altair and Vega cross align. The Sendai Tanabata Matsuri is held every year between the 6th and 8th of August and is one of the largest and most famous Tanabata festivals in Japan. Many festivities take place throughout downtown Sendai, with the main feature being thousands of colourful streamers decorating the city’s shopping arcades, which resemble brightly coloured forests.These are handcrafted by local community groups and schools out of traditional paper and bamboo.
sources.shortName: Sendai Travel Guide - 9 Best things to do in Sendai

sources.snippet: Sendai is known for Sendai Tanabata Festival in early August. Tanabata is an ancient Japanese tradition based on a legend about the doomed romance between the weaving princess Orihime and the cow-herding Hikoboshi. When the lovers pay more attention to their relationship than their responsibility, Hikoboshi’s cows escaped, wreaking havoc among the heavens.
sources.shortName: 6 Best Things to Do in Sendai

sources.snippet: Surrounded by the sea and mountains, the area is blessed with a wide variety of delicious foods and exciting events, including the Sendai Tanabata Festival, Sendai Pageant of Starlight, and the Ogawara Cherry Blossom Festival, which are held throughout the spring, summer, autumn, and winter. Read on to find out about Sendai and things to do there.
sources.shortName: 35 things to do in Sendai: Festivals, nature, and attractions

sources.snippet: A summer tradition of Japanese paper decorated on green bamboo and the wind. Over 3,000 bamboo decorations form an arch in the city of Sendai. At the Sendai Tanabata Fireworks Festival, held the eve of the festival, about 16,000 fireworks are launched in a spectacular display.
sources.siteName: ホテルグランバッハ - Hotel GrandBach
sources.shortName: Sendai: Local sightseeing | Hotel GrandBach

sources.snippet: Picture courtesy of Miyagi Prefectural Government Tourism Division. The Sendai Tanabata Festival is a summer tradition annually held from August 6 – 8. The festival has been held ever since the time of Date Masamune as the lord of Sendai Castle.
sources.shortName: Top 20 Things to Do in Sendai: Travel Guide 2024

sources.snippet: In summer, there are Sendai tanabata festival, fireworks, Sendai aoba matsuri, and jozenji street jazz festival. There are a lot of events in a whole year. Every year many tourists from whole country visit these events.
sources.shortName: Sendai Events and Tourist Information｜Sendai Gyu-town

places.name: Sendai Tanabata Festival

reviews.text:
The Sendai Tanabata Festival, annually celebrated on August 6th, 7th and 8th, is a personal and family favorite from throughout the years.  From my childhood to youth, the Kroehler family traveled to our summer cottage on the Shichigahama shoreline in Miyagi Prefecture, just due east, outside of the Sendai metropolitan area.  As a family, we often drove into Sendai (or took the train from Tagajo Station) in order to attend the festival.  The iconic, mesmerizing very colorful streamers annually invited (welcomed) large local crowds and visitors from around the world.

I knew the general love-story, which underpinned this remarkable annual celebration.  There were reasons for the countless ferverent prayers and pleas for good weather throughout the night on August 7th.  But, not until now, have I carefully researched the underlying background to this very popular Japanese celebration with deep historical Chinese roots and legacy.  Here then, is my first attempt, to describe the important highlights of this popular star-studded ancient Chinese poem.

The Tanabata Festival in Sendai, based upon an ancient Chinese love-story, now widespread throughout Japan, is celebrated (according to the Chinese calendar) each year over the three days of August 6th, 7th and 8th.  Others in Japan attend Tanabata events on July 7th.  This romance is a bitter-sweet, hopeful account of an fleeting-moment rendevous under ideal, good weather circumatances. Visitor from throughout Japan and around the world, press into the arcade to view these spectacular, lively streamers. They gracefully hang from high arcade arches above (and, perhaps, some would say reach into the heavens). Individuals of all ages stand below their beautiful stunningly individually crafted, very special, colorful unforgettable forms.  But, the underlying amazing and captivating ancient Chinese poem is equally remarkable as well as awe inspiring.

I wanted to carefully investigate the history of this awe-inspiring legend, which I have have heard throughout my childhood, youth and now into my adult life.  What I found, deeply impressed me.  The contours of this very popular legendary account, kept it's basic highlights and storyline.  But, the specific details of the fairy- tale poem varied substantially.  Also, I wanted to devine Asian attitudes toward the magpies, which play a critical, all-important role in this narrative.  I came across remarkable findings about East Asian Chinese, Korean, and Japanese views about this very special, lucky bird.  These results follow in my narrative.  May you, my reader, become infatuated, and yes fully, hopelessly immersed in the story / poem details, storyline and final joyful outcome.

My research reveals these facts.  This love story, from records, goes back 2,600 years ago to the Chinese Han dynasty dated (202B.C.-220A.D.) in one account (206B.C.-220A.D.) in another.  Later, the storyline evolved in "Classic of Poetry," more than 2,500 years ago, a Tang Dynasty (618-907A.D.) Era poem, called the "Tian He" or "The Heavenly River." And, still later during the Song Dynasty (960-1279), the Que Qiao Xia or "Immortals At The Magpie Bridge" added further details.  The storyline evolved.

In time, Sendai embraced the Tanabata Star Festival under Sendai Daimyo (Warlord) Date Masamune (1567-1636).  Sendaians celebrate this festival according to the Chinese lunar calendar on August 7th (including 6th and 8th), other regions across Japan observe Tanabata on July 7th, under the modern Roman calendar.

Truly, in this context, folk-tales and poems too can offer forward-looking benefits regarding pride of hard work, persistence and a sincere eternal hope in future possibilities and good fortune.  HINT:  How many different types of values can YOU identify, which underpin this remarkable story?  I count at least seven (a lucky number). And, YOU?

Please carefully study my images and accompanying commentary.  So YOU too, my reader, can star-gaze, dream and envision your own optimistic future. What wonderful future opportunities await you on the horizon?
Giant Tanabata decorations line the shopping streets outside Sendai station

(Translated by Google) One of Tohoku's four major festivals, the Sendai Tanabata Festival is a magnificent traditional festival that dates back to the time of Date Masamune. Gorgeous Tanabata decorations adorn the streets, seven kinds of wish sticks with various wishes draw attention, and a variety of events are held to entertain the public.

Sendai City in Miyagi Prefecture, the largest city in the Tohoku region and known as the "Mori no Toku" (Mori-no-Mori), hosts the Sendai Tanabata Festival for three days each year from August 6th to 8th. This spectacular festival attracts approximately two million tourists, and not only downtown Sendai and its surrounding shopping districts, but also throughout the city itself, is adorned with magnificent Tanabata decorations.

Tanabata originates from Chinese legend, narrating the annual meeting of the stars Altair and Vega across the Milky Way. The practice of "Qiqiaodian," which encourages people to emulate the skilled weaver girl and improve their craftsmanship, is said to have been introduced to Japan during the Nara period.

The most compelling theory regarding the origins of the Sendai Tanabata Festival is that it was popularized as an annual festival by Date Masamune (1567-1636), the founder of the Sendai clan.

The festival's Tanabata decorations include the "Seven Decorations." Traditionally, Japanese people write wishes on long strips of paper called "tansho" (prayers) and then hang them on bamboo branches as decorations.

The Sendai Tanabata Festival features seven decorations: "tansho" (prayers), which pray for academic advancement and calligraphy; "kinsho" (wealth and savings); "kinsho" (drawstring bags for coins and small items); "shirō" (cleanliness and thriftiness); "casting nets" (a bountiful catch); "paper cranes" (safety and longevity for the family); "wind banners" (improvement in weaving techniques); and "paper clothes" (improvement in tailoring skills and protection from misfortune).
A distinctive feature of the festival is the three-dimensional sphere, resembling a "kaedo," atop each of the seven decorations. As these Tanabata decorations reach nearly five meters in length, the spectacle is truly breathtaking. The traditional wind streamers, made of Japanese paper, rustle in the wind, bringing a refreshing coolness to the sweltering summer heat.
Walking along the beautiful streets, one can almost feel the joyful atmosphere of the time, and the overwhelming emotion lingers deeply in one's heart, leaving behind everlasting memories.

(Original)
東北四大祭典「仙台七夕祭」：始於伊達政宗時代的華麗絢爛的傳統祭典。華麗絢爛的七夕裝飾點綴整條街道・寫上各種願望的「七種祈願籤裝飾」引人矚目・同時舉辦各式多彩的活動，讓人樂在其中。
以「杜之都」之名為人所知的東北地方最大都市・宮城縣仙台市，每年8月6～8日會舉辦為期3天的「仙台七夕祭」。吸引約莫200萬人的觀光客前來共襄盛舉的一大祭典，除了仙台的市中心和周邊商店街，市內各地也都點綴著「七夕裝飾」，美輪美奐。

「七夕」的典故來自中國傳說，牛郎星和織女星每年一次會渡過銀河相見的故事。希望向擅長織布的織女看齊，祈求手藝精進的「乞巧奠」活動，據傳是奈良時代傳到日本的。

關於「仙台七夕祭」的起源，最有力的說法是在仙台藩祖・伊達政宗（1567～1636年）的推廣下，成為年節慶典普及開來。

祭典的七夕裝飾有不可或缺的「七種裝飾」。通常，日本的七夕會在被稱為「短冊」的長條紙上寫下心願－－祈願籤，然後掛在的竹枝上做為裝飾。

仙台七夕祭有祈求學問和書法進步的「短冊」（祈願籤）、「巾著（富貴、儲蓄）」（巾著是指收納零錢或小物的束口袋）、「屑籠（整潔和節儉）」（屑籠指裝紙屑的容器）、「投網（漁獲豐收）」、「紙鶴（闔家平安、長壽）」、「風幡（精進織布技術）」、「紙衣（裁縫技巧精進、消災解厄）」，由這7種裝飾來點綴。
7種裝飾的最頂端會裝上像「彩球」這樣的立體球型，是一大特色。因為這些七夕裝飾的全長接近5公尺，所以景象頗為壯觀，為之震撼。習慣使用和紙製作的風幡，隨風搖曳，發出沙沙的聲響，為炎熱的夏天帶來一陣涼爽。
走在美麗的街道上，仿佛可以感受到當時愉悦的氣氣氛，滿滿的感動仍留在心底深處，永遠的回憶。

places.address: 3 Chome-2 Ichibancho, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0811, Japan

places.generalDescription: Aoba Castle Honmaru Hall, perched atop a hill, is a national historic monument that offers visitors a glimpse into Japan's feudal past. Originally founded in 1610 by the legendary Date Masamune, this site was strategically chosen for its defensive advantages and has since evolved into the well-organized city layout we see today. Although much of the castle was lost to fire and wartime destruction, remnants like stone walls still evoke its former grandeur.
places.name: Aoba Castle Honmaru Hall (Miyagi Prefecture Gokoku Shrine Event Venue)

reviews.text: Stunning view of Sendai. We stayed up there a while just enjoying the view 🥰 and left only because it got too cold.

Excellent option to visit some tourist attraction here in Sendai, there is no charge to enter to see the Aoba castle, there is a souvenir shop and a store to buy food at the top, although as a recommendation if you are going to climb it walking be in a bit of condition or in case of elderly adults bring a wheelchair, the views of the city are incredible 🏙️ 🌃 🌆 ⚔️ 🏰 🇯🇵

I was unfortunately disappointed with my visit to Sendai Castle. Hardly any elements have been restored. Therefore, there is not much to discover. There are lots of parking lots on the mountain. The shrine is quite beautiful and the view over the city is also quite good. However, the long journey on the tourist bus is not necessarily worth it.

places.address: 1 Kawauchi, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0862, Japan

sources.snippet: For the meeting point and directions of the romantic tour in Sendai, participants are instructed to gather at the main entrance of Mototerakoji Catholic Church. This picturesque church is located at 1 Chome-2-12 Honcho, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi, Japan.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Sendai
Romantic Tour In Sendai – Opatrip

places.name: Mototerakoji Catholic Church

reviews.text:
A very convenient place to attend mass even when you are far from home.
Sunday mass timetable is 0700, 0930 & 1800.
Very active internationally

This is the Cathedral for Sendai and seat of the Bishop of all Tohoku. Modern but tasteful interior. Walking distance to Sendai Station. Limited free parking on-site during Mass, but it fills up fast. Paid parking options nearby.

places.address: カトリック仙台司教区センター, 1 Chome-2-12 Honcho, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0014, Japan

places.generalDescription: Jozenji-dori Avenue is a stunning tree-lined street in Sendai, renowned for its majestic zelkova trees and captivating bronze sculptures. Stretching 700 meters from Nishi Park to Kotodai Park, this picturesque avenue offers a delightful blend of nature and urban life. Visitors can enjoy vibrant greenery in spring, colorful autumn leaves, and enchanting winter illuminations that create an inviting atmosphere year-round.

sources.snippet: Picture courtesy of Miyagi Prefectural Government Tourism Division. Jozenji-dori Avenue is a Japanese zelkova-lined avenue located right next to Kotodai Park, two stations away from Sendai Station. Rows of Japanese zelkova trees surround the central promenade, decorating the avenue with bright green leaves in spring, colorful foliage in fall, and sparkling illuminations in the winter, delighting those that visit.
sources.shortName: Top 20 Things to Do in Sendai: Travel Guide 2024

sources.snippet: Jōzenji-dōri Avenue (定禅寺通) is a tree-lined avenue that runs through the centre of Sendai from east to west. The avenue delights passers-by with its seasonal scenery: lush greens in spring and summer, hues of yellow in autumn, and snow-covered scenes in winter. Shops and restaurants line the street, and the sidewalks bustle with people on their way home from work and on weekends.
sources.shortName: Unlock Sendai With Our Guide To Must-See Places!

sources.snippet: If you’re planning a winter trip to Sendai, don’t miss the Sendai Pageant of Light, held from mid-December to the end of the year in Sendai City. 420,000 LED bulbs light up the zelkova trees along Jozenji-dori, one of Sendai’s main streets, creating a beautiful tunnel of light, and the central promenade makes you feel as if you’re surrounded by light.
sources.shortName: 35 things to do in Sendai: Festivals, nature, and attractions

sources.snippet: Jozenji-dori is a popular street lined with Japanese Zelkova trees. Here you will find Sendai Mediatheque, housing galleries and cafes, as well as the nightspot of Kokubunji. In December, the Sendai Pageant of Starlight sees the Zelkova trees illuminated by 600,000 lights.
sources.shortName: LOCAL GUIDE｜Hotel Monte Hermana Sendai

sources.snippet: Ichibancho is an area that stretches from in front of the AER Building next to Sendai Station, several blocks to Jozenji-dori Avenue. The covered pedestrian mall is filled with shops big and small. Find everything from fashion, cosmetics, souvenirs, food, and more.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Things To Do in Sendai - Sendai, Miyagi

sources.snippet: The zelkova trees that line Jozenji-dori Avenue are illuminated with some 600,000 lights to create a romantic winter spectacle. The “starlight wink” effect when the lights flicker off and on again is truly breathtaking.
sources.siteName: Discover SENDAI | Sendai Official Tourism Website
sources.shortName: Highlights of Winter in Sendai

sources.snippet: The beautiful tree-lined streets between the buildings are a perfect example of the image of the "City of Forests.". Address: Near Kokubuncho 2-chome, Aoba-ku, Sendai city
sources.siteName: ホテルグランバッハ - Hotel GrandBach
sources.shortName: Sendai: Local sightseeing | Hotel GrandBach
38 Best Things to Do in Sendai & Miyagi: Sightseeing, Food, Shopping & Souvenirs

places.name: Jozenji-dori Ave

reviews.text: One of the best favorite streets in Japan. In all season you can enjoy landscape and the atmosphere of the forest city.

There is nothing much to see here except a densely tree-lined walkway with some sculptures. It is a nice walk, and from other's photo, it looks like the trees will be decorated with lights and they will light up when it's festive season. And that does look pretty impressive. Otherwise, I wouldn't waste time to come here unless you are already here for something else.

They hold a Jazz Festival each year here.  we attended it the second weekend of September.  Lots of bands and free admission.  Food trucks everywhere as well as beer trucks.  The bandstands were in the parks.

places.generalDescription: When visiting Sendai, make sure to include a visit to the Sendai Castle Ruins (Aoba Castle Ruins) on your itinerary. This historical site offers stunning panoramic views of the city and was originally built by Date Masamune in the 17th century. The castle's plateau location provides a picturesque backdrop for exploring its rich history and enjoying breathtaking vistas of Sendai.

sources.snippet: Additionally, there are popular tourist attractions and historical sites related to Date Masamune (the legendary Japanese military commander of the Warring States period who laid the foundations for Sendai City), such as Sendai Castle Ruins and Zuihoden. There are also two hot springs located about 30 minutes by car from the center of the city.
sources.shortName: 35 things to do in Sendai: Festivals, nature, and attractions

sources.snippet: Aoba Castle was built in 1600 by the powerful feudal lord Date Masamune. The castle was located on Mount Aoba, 100 meters above the town. Currently the castle is almost completely gone after a fire left only its stone walls as a reminder to what once must have been a majestic castle.
sources.shortName: 6 Best Things to Do in Sendai

sources.snippet: Sendai Castle was built in 1602 by Date Masamune, the first lord of the Sendai domain. Known for his refined sense of style, Masamune inspired the term Date-otoko, referring to fashionable men. His iconic crescent-moon helmet even influenced Darth Vader’s design in Star Wars.
sources.shortName: 38 Best Things to Do in Sendai & Miyagi: Sightseeing, Food, Shopping & Souvenirs

sources.snippet: The area around the castle ruins, affectionately known as Aoba Castle, is now Aobayama Park, from which you can enjoy a panoramic view of Sendai city and the Pacific Ocean. Address: 1 Kawauchi, Aoba Ward, Sendai City
sources.siteName: ホテルグランバッハ - Hotel GrandBach
sources.shortName: Sendai: Local sightseeing | Hotel GrandBach

sources.snippet: Picture courtesy of Miyagi Prefectural Government Tourism Division. Sendai Castle is the castle of Date Masamune, also known as Aoba Castle. It is a natural stronghold surrounded by cliffs to the east and south.
sources.shortName: Top 20 Things to Do in Sendai: Travel Guide 2024

places.name: Sendai Castle Ruins (Aoba Castle Ruins)

reviews.text:
One of the famous places in Sendai city. Not very far from Sendai station.  There is a loop bus for every 20mins. By taxi around ¥1500.
Famous for Tate statue, iconic place in Sendai. If the weather is good, Sendai city view is good.
For car park, have to pay some money.

First of all, there is no castle, so that you don't go with this expectation. However the ground where the castle used to be offers a great view of the city of Sendai and there are signs offering information about the history. There is a large statue of Date Masamune, the lord that established the city of Sendai. There is a quite large souvenir shop with some interesting souvenirs to buy (most however are things you can see and buy everywhere). There is a small food court where you can eat. You can try the zunda shake, based on edamame (I know it doesn't sound right but, trust me, try it).
The "hike" to the top is quite physical so it's a nice little challenge. I saw however people bringing their luggage with them so don't do that. Otherwise, if you don't feel like working, there is a bus that can take you to the top. Either way, it's worth the detour.

To be honest, it's a tourist trap. Admission is free, but the 3 tiny museums are 700, 300, and 465 yen and very, very not worth that price. We walked into the 465 yen one without realizing it was paid, and I'm glad we didn't get charged because there was literally 3 things to see in a teeny room. Altogether with the free stuff, it's barely worth the price. You can see everything in an hour, max. Unless you really want to see the view, it's not worth coming all the way up here. The city museum and mausoleum have much better cost performance.

places.address: 1番地, Kawauchi, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0862, Japan

sources.snippet: Traveling to Sendai by bus is a cheaper alternative to trains and flights. Major bus providers like Willer Express, JR Bus, and Tobu Bus have daily services from Tokyo, Osaka, and other major cities. The journey takes around 5-6 hours depending on where you are coming from and where you are going.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A 2 day romantic trip to Sendai, Japan

places.name: Miyagi Kotsu Sendai Highway Bus Center

reviews.text: waiting here is very comfortable, cause outside is very cold xoxoxo

It good place for relax and waiting a highway bus. Wifi and toilet free to use. You can get a rental locker from 30-1000 yen. You can buy  ticket with a ticket vending machine here or ask the staff for the information

I had a very very bad experience with one of the staff. I went there with a question, is there any bus going to Niigata from here?
One of the staff replied with no no no niigata, I was putting my hand on the counter because I was showing him like a translation. Out of nowhere after he said that he was kinda pushing my hand away like leave leave like if I am a beggar or something. Sametime he was calling the person after me to come. Very very very very rude, this is a new level. It was very strange that the lady next to him after he did that, didn't even say a word. She was just watching like she is watching a show or something. Cold and rude.

places.address: 東京建物仙台ビル １F, 1 Chome-6-35 Central, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0021, Japan

places.generalDescription: The Sightseeing Boat Pier offers a delightful way to explore the stunning islands of Matsushima, even if Sendai itself isn't directly accessible by boat. While you can embark on a ferry from Tokyo to Sendai, the real gem lies in the scenic boat tours available at this pier. With various courses like the Niomaru and Masamune routes, visitors can enjoy breathtaking views of uniquely shaped islands while learning about their history through informative commentary onboard.

sources.snippet:
Locations related to Masamune Date（one of the most famous samurai warriors in Japanese history) are an essential part of sightseeing in Sendai, but these tend to be a little far from Sendai Station. For a smooth experience of touring these locations, we recommend taking the Loople Sendai tour bus, which departs from Sendai Station.
 Photograph courtesy of: Miyagi Prefecture Tourism Division
sources.siteName: Experience | Hotel Metropolitan Sendai East[Official]｜Hotel Metropolitan Sendai East[Official]
sources.shortName: Experience | Hotel Metropolitan Sendai East[Official]

sources.snippet: There is no direct boat service to Sendai as it is not a coastal city. However, you can take a ferry from Tokyo to Sendai via the Shinjuku Ferry Terminal in Tokyo. The journey takes around 12 hours but can be a relaxing and unique way to experience Japan's coastline.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A 2 day romantic trip to Sendai, Japan

places.name: Sightseeing Boat Pier

reviews.text: The boat ride was very good. You get to view the different shaped islands in the bay from the boat. The speakers on the boat provide information on the islands. There are different rides ranging from thirty minutes long to two hours.

Learn the different islands in matsushima bay and their backstories. Such as small caves, lion stacks, Shiogama city and more. A really fun experience including the thrill of the wind blowing against you. Matsushima's waters are superb in terms of quality. The boat experience is not rough to the slightest. When booking a trip the seats are first come first serve so make sure to go early before it departs.
1 hour boat tour for around 1000-1500yen. It's a nice option to enjoy small islands scenery around Matsushima in comfort. There's extra 600yen if you want to be seated on the 2nd floor of the ship.

places.address: Chonai-98-1 Matsushima, 松島町 Matsushima, Miyagi District, Miyagi 981-0213, Japan

places.generalDescription: Hirose River, flowing through the heart of the city, is a prime location for enjoying stunning fireworks displays. The river offers unobstructed views from various spots in the city, with paid viewing areas like Nishi-Koen Park providing optimal vantage points. Additionally, it serves as a fishing ground for sea bass and is an integral part of Sendai's seasonal charm as it flows around the city throughout the year.

sources.snippet: The fireworks shoot up into the sky from the Hirose River, which runs through the middle of the city, and you can see them from any unobstructed city location. Find your favorite spot and revel in the breathtaking fireworks. Numerous paid viewing areas are available, particularly in and around Nishi-Koen Park, offering optimal views of the spectacular fireworks.
sources.shortName: Wonderful Journey to Enjoy Romantic Summer Nights at “Sendai Tanabata Festival”

sources.snippet: Nearby attractions, such as the bustling shopping street of Ichibancho and the peaceful Hirose River, await to be explored on this enchanting tour.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Sendai

places.name: Hirose River

reviews.text: The namesake of the most reliable person in all of Duwang
Got rid of my daughter just to get this reliable dude. Approved
The most reliable guy I know has his own river. The more you know.

places.generalDescription: The Bust of Date Masamune is a tribute to the legendary warrior and founder of Sendai, known for his strategic prowess and iconic eyepatch. Located at the foot of Aoba Castle, this bust offers a clear view of Masamune's face, unlike the equestrian statue higher up. While exploring Sendai Castle ruins, visitors can also encounter a statue depicting Masamune on horseback.

sources.snippet: Feudal samurai lord Date Masamune, better known and feared by his enemies as the "One-eyed Dragon", founded Sendai over 400 years ago. Many tourist attractions relate to him or his clan predecessors. His story is one of struggle, violence, passion of the arts, and ever lasting achievements.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Things To Do in Sendai - Sendai, Miyagi

places.name: Bust of Date Masamune

reviews.text: À must to stop in Sendai. Great seesight place to spend with family with places to eat.

Nice statue with the view of Sendai city. Thr walk up from the foot of the hill was quite a treat.

There's parking on the other side but we chose to park at the foot of the hill and walked up through the park.

(Translated by Google) The remaining part of the first generation, which was removed due to metal donation. I think it stayed well. The previous one was at the Sendai City Museum, and it left a strong impression on me. It was relocated and can now be seen in contrast with the statue at Sendai Castle.

(Original)
金属供出で撤去された初代で残っていた部分。よく残っていたと思います。前は仙台市博物館にあって強く印象に残っていました。移設され仙台城にある像との対比で一緒に眺められるようになりました。

places.address: 26 Kawauchi, Aoba Ward, Sendai, Miyagi 980-0862, Japan
